content:
San Jose Mercury News (California)

                              June 23, 2014 Monday

Facebook's new tracking practices; Silicon Valley's dynamic duos; more




Troy Wolverton writes : Facebook users beware: The company has -- yet again --
unilaterally changed its mind about its data collection practices. As users
should know, that's not a good thing for their privacy.

A host of startups, including ActivityHero, ActivityTree, Camperoo and
Famtivity, have sprung up to streamline the process for parents who want to
patch together summer activities for their kids .

Google+, Google's social network, is 3 years old . It hasn't come close to
Facebook's popularity as a digital town square, though enthusiasts use it for
photo-sharing, video chats and sometimes passionate debates.

Michelle Quinn writes : Americans admire the lone-wolf myth, and in business
that means the bold industrialist creating something from nothing. But in
Silicon Valley, we tend to celebrate duos, cultural icons linked forever like
Simon and Garfunkel, or Sonny and Cher.

Larry Magid writes about the Aspen Institute's proposed changes to education:
With modern technology there are no more excuses for education to remain in the
dark ages.

Mercury News interview : Marty Beard, CEO of LiveOps, which provides cloud-based
call centers.

The Bay Area added 6,500 jobs in May, powered mainly by gains in the East Bay,
which offset modest job losses in Santa Clara County and the San Francisco area,
the state announced Friday.

GRAPHIC: (FILES) This January 30, 2014 file photo taken in Washington,DC, shows
the splash page for the social media internet site Facebook. Facebook said June
12, 2014 it would begin allowing users more information about the ads delivered
to them, and to block marketing messages they don't want to see. In a blog post,
Facebook said its users "tell us they want more control over the ads they see"
and that the huge social network is responding to that. "That's why we're
introducing ad preferences, a new tool accessible from every ad on Facebook that
explains why you're seeing a specific ad and lets you add and remove interests
that we use to show you ads," the post said. AFP PHOTO / Karen BLEIERKAREN
BLEIER/AFP/Getty Images
